climbs.name: The TET Offensive
climbs.fa: Tony Sartin, E. Roed, T. Condon    Sept. 2008

content.description: The difficulties of this route begin after the second roof on a clean, white face of bullet rock. After negotiating this thin section of climbing, pull the crux roof and continue up a sometimes steep and sometimes scruffy moderate section to a two bolt lower off at the top of the cliff.
content.protection: 15 bolts to a two bolt lower off. This route is a full 35 meters and requires all of a 70 meter rope. Please always tie a knot in the end of your rope. It originally had an exciting run-out section above the second roof. It has since been retro-bolted and is now quite tame.
content.location: Begins a few feet left of "Cone of Silence" in a tricky, white, right facing dihedral.

climbs.name: Supersizer
climbs.fa: Erik Roed, T. Sartin, and K. Daniels,  Sept. 2009

content.description: A vegetated and chossy start leads to better rock and a tiered double roof with a chain draw. Above this point the rock improves dramatically. Pull the roofs, exiting the second one to the right. Stem up a beautiful thin face to another roof section. Again, exit to the right and continue up another tricky face on bullet rock. Encounter a thin crux section just before the wall bulges. Move left at the base of the steepness and climb on the left side of the wild arete, clipping chain draws to your right. finish at a two bolt lower off.
content.protection: 14 bolts, some are chain draws. Two bolt lower off at top of cliff.
content.location: Begins 10 feet right of the Polarizer in a scrappy right facing dihedral. Lower off with a 70 meter rope. Please remember to knot the end of your rope!

climbs.name: Right Again
climbs.fa: Karine Croft, Peter Croft, Marty Lewis, Kevin Calder, Jay Zimmerman, 06/1999

content.description: Start on Garden Route, then deviate right after the fifth bolt. Cross over Hamster Style, and continue up past a dihedral and a 10+ crux move.

climbs.name: The Polarizer
climbs.fa: Tony Sartin and Erik Roed,      Oct. 2009

content.description: Big holds and easy climbing at the start leads to a steep section followed by a great stem rest out left. From the rest, traverse back right into a well protected thin crux section. A clean face above leads to a tricky roof move followed by moderate climbing to the anchor. This was an old, one bolt Marty Lewis project. It is letter I in the Mammoth Area Rock Climbs guidebook on page 140.
content.protection: 14 bolts, some with chain draws, lead to a two bolt lower off.
content.location: Begins 25 feet right of The Moisturizer in a scruffy, right facing corner. The base of the route is located at the right edge of a large patch of bushes that choke access to the cliff. You can just make the lower-off with a 70 meter rope. Knot the end of your rope!

content.description: This climb is mega! begin in a seeping dihedral, angling up and left around a column to another, cleaner dihedral. Stem past crux moves between the 4th and 5th bolt to easier climbing up to a ledge. From here, excellent face climbing on blocky holds and clean, bullet rock leads to a restful stance just under the wild overhang which guards the summit. Tackle the steepness on positive holds, gunning for the skyline. It's best to clip the anchor after you get your hands over the summit block.
content.protection:
16 bolts. Double steel biner lower off at the top of the cliff.

35 meter route, 70 meter rope reguired.
content.location:
Begins 15 feet right of Hamster Style, in a seeping dihedral between grossly vegetated walls on either side.

WARNING!!! This climb uses all of a stretched 70 meter rope to get down. Please tie a stopper knot in the end of your rope.

content.description: This long and slightly confusing climb, features interesting climbing up dihedral-like columns.  The start is a little chossy, but the rock quickly improves.  At the top, make sure to go straight (the left line of bolts) and not end up on the finish of Right Again.

Sustained vertical columns, somewhat sporty. Like most routes at the Teflon Wall, crux is towards the top. First bolted line at the Bear Crag, originally topped out after climbing a pumice slope up and right.
content.location: Right of a big tree root, in between Cupcake (11c) and Right Again (10d)

content.description: Considered a squeeze job. Vertical column leads to a left-leaning corner. Crux near the anchors.
content.location: Right of Cable Guy (11d), Left of Garden Route (11c)

content.description: Dihedrals lead to a roof crux about 3/4 of the way up. Excellent rock!
content.location: Starts left of a fallen tree, first route left of Cable Guy (11d)

content.description: Gently overhanging dihedrals lead to a thin face, then blast through a roof.
content.location: Just right of Cone of Silence (12a). Starts directly above a fallen tree.
